content.description:
Sodium hydroxide can be produced commercially from the electrolysis of sodium chloride solutions, as indicated by the following balanced equation.

<math alttext="2 N a C l aqueous plus 2 H 2 O liquid, react to produce 2 N a O H aqueous plus C l 2 gas, plus H 2 gas. delta G naught, equals 400 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>400</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: The gases produced from the electrolysis reaction are condensed in order to prevent their escape into the atmosphere. Which of the following indicates the gas that condenses at the lower temperature and gives a particle-level explanation for why?

choices.label: <math alttext="H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the hydrogen bonding in <math alttext="H 2 liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is stronger than the dispersion forces in <math alttext="C l 2 liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the dispersion forces in <math alttext="H 2 liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are weaker than the dispersion forces in <math alttext="C l 2 liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the <math alttext="C l, C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bond in <math alttext="C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is stronger than the <math alttext="H, H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bond in <math alttext="H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></math> atoms are more electronegative than <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms.

content.answer: <math alttext="H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the dispersion forces in <math alttext="H 2 liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are weaker than the dispersion forces in <math alttext="C l 2 liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 6.C: Support a claim with evidence from representations or models at the particulate level, such as the structure of atoms and/or molecules.
